MainClaim.text: "Currie's rejection of weak illusionism is sound because cinematic motion is real

Untitled2.text: "Cinematic motion is not illusory in the weak sense

Untitled3.text: "Cinematic motion is real in the weak sense

Untitled4.text: "The experience of film requires specific reception conditions

Untitled5.text: "The speed of projection is a necessary condition for the reception of the art form of film."

Untitled6.text: "The nature of cinematic motion must be considered independently from the means used to produce the motion."

Untitled7.text: "Currie's theory of cinematic motion is the most plausible of the three options."

Untitled9.text: "The discussion about cinematic motion is about the art form of film

Untitled10.text: "Cinematic motion is the real movement of singletons."

Untitled11.text: "Ponech's theory fails because singletons are not objects."

Untitled12.text: "Ponech's attempt to prove that singletons exhibit garden-variety motion fails."

Untitled13.text: "Currie's theory of cinematic motion is the most plausible of the three options."

Untitled14.text: "Currie's rejection of weak illusionism is sound."

Untitled15.text: "The fact that cinematic motion is produced by static frames shows only that a certain speed of projection is a reception condition of the art form."

Untitled16.text: "The analogy with the Müller-Lyer illusion breaks down once one departs from the reception conditions of the art form."

Untitled18.text: "The experience of film is the experience of seeing moving images under specific perceptual circumstances."

Untitled19.text: "The necessary conditions for an audience to experience the work of art include the speed of projection."

Untitled20.text: "The art form of film is independent of the specific medium used in production."

Untitled21.text: "The nature of cinematic motion must be considered independently from the means used to produce the motion."

Untitled22.text: "The view that the illusory nature of film can be proved by slowing the projector down is doubly fallacious."

Untitled23.text: "Currie's theory of cinematic motion is the most plausible of the three options."

Untitled25.text: "The discussion is about film and the art of film involves certain necessary reception conditions."

Untitled26.text: "Currie has already identified film as essentially moving pictures."

Untitled27.text: "Cinematic motion is the real movement of singletons."

Untitled28.text: "The fact that cinematic motion is produced by static frames shows only that a certain speed of projection is a reception condition of the art form."

Untitled29.text: "The analogy with the Müller-Lyer illusion breaks down once one departs from the reception conditions of the art form."
